address.streetAddress: 95 Front St E Upper Level of the St. Lawrence Market

description: Explore the sights and sounds of the historic South St. Lawrence Market, site of Toronto's 19th century City Hall, with a visit to the Market Gallery, where you'll find exhibits and programs on the art, culture and history of Toronto presented in the original city council chamber.

reviews.title: Interesting market, small museum
text: The Market Gallery is located in the upper level of the St. Lawrence Market on Front Street. The market itself is interesting to walk through and has several food-service stalls. The Gallery itself is just one large room, containing exhibits about the development of brewing beer and ale in southern Ontario. Access is by elevator near the main doors. There are public washrooms in the basement.

reviews.title: Don’t miss the show on women artists
text: This quiet, little-known Museum over the bustling St. Lawrence Market is either a Quinn quick in-and-out or a spot for serious contemplation, depending on what’s on. The current show on Toronto through the eyes of women artists is the best I’ve seen there. Although the 19th-century artists are of mostly historical interest, the works get increasingly powerful as the show’s arc bends toward the present. I’ll be returning for a longer look at pieces I particularly liked, most by artists new to me. Don’t miss the 27-minute doc on Russian-born Paraskeva Clark, who at 81 was colourful, quotable and subversively charming.

reviews.title: Very fine exhibit of works by women painters
text: Last Saturday the Market Gallery offered free admission to their show of women painters and their depictions of Toronto, from the late 19th century to the recent past. The works are a selection from those held by the City of Toronto. I was particularly pleased to see works by Paraskeva Clark and Doris McCarthy, but there are many other very good pieces. This show should not be missed. It runs into April.

reviews.title: "Bike City" a nice show BUT
text: But I feel the new admission fee is too much for such a small space.  The show about the history of bikes in Toronto included ephemera, posters, old bike license plates and about a dozen bicycles.

reviews.title: A large ripoff
text: The Market Gallery is a small overpriced room virtually impossible to locate with small traveling exhibitions. If you want to lose $15 (Adult + Youth) then you can see this it is located upstairs from the main entrance to the market with an elevator and two deserted stairwells. We saw an exhibit on the Cycling Culture of Toronto you could learn everything with a 10-minute free web search.

reviews.title: Don't miss this place . . . .
text: Two things; 1. go and enjoy yourself.  2. if you are NOT from Canada make sure you have Canadian money as no one will do the exchange rate, there so if it is $10 Canadian and you have $10 U.S. forgot the 20% off they want $10 period so if you pay with a U.S. dollar you lose 20%. MAKE SURE you go to the bank and do the exchange. There are MANY good places to sample food and other goods from the local area. Take your time and try the poutine (just a hint) don't forget dessert. Enjoy

reviews.title: Good archaeological display
text: The old North (or Farmers') Market having been torn down, archaeologists have been able to sort out the remains from earlier days before work on the new North Market. The result is a small but fascinating exhibition on the history of the building and the various objects found below it. The exhibition ends in mid-March; try to see it while you can.

reviews.title: Beatles Rock Toronto
text: Delightful exhibit about The Beatles and the music scene in Toronto in the 1960s.  Nostalgic and informative, was well curated and organized.  Don't miss this

reviews.title: The Beatles!!
text: The Exhibit "When the Beatles Rocked Toronto" was so worth it.  Talk about a time warp.   Well organized and the videos are such fun, oh the screaming girls!   The wall mounted timeline about the changes to TO were informative, dare I say educational!
And then you can buy Quebec Cheese downstairs!

reviews.title: Nice, but mostly food
text: Nice, but mostly food. Several small gallery type stores mixed in. Go for the food, not for the gallery stores.

reviews.title: Cute little gallery in a thriving market
text: The gallery itself is a little hard to find. The entrance is right at the main entrance to the St. Lawrence market and really easy to miss. The market has lots of other entrances but no signage to point you to the gallery.
Once inside (all the way up) I really enjoyed their exhibit "Tunnerl Vision" although small, it was really interesting nonetheless and you also had a great view of the market from the gallery.

reviews.title: Nice space; good exhibitions
text: It's rewarding to check out the Market Gallery from time to time, for the exhibitions are generally worthwhile. The current one, showing works recently acquired for the City of Toronto art collection, is no exception. As an added bonus you get a nice view over the South Market. Definitely recommended!

reviews.title: A little bit of peace
text: When the market overwhelms your senses take some time out upstairs at the Market Gallery. Large, airy, spacious and peaceful,  featuring works from various eras and genres. You have a small insight into Toronto culture and history.  Also loved the large windows overlooking the market. Some lovely photo opportunities. The staff were really friendly and knowledgeable.  Definitely worth a visit.

reviews.title: ANOTHER VERY INTERESTING PLACE TO LOOK FOR
text: Most shoppers have visited the famous St. Lawrence Market at one point or another down through the years while few have ever checked into the ever-changing informative historical displays and exhibits located above in The Market Gallery where these very interesting Toronto artifacts may be found ...
Things  change  through  the  seasons  so  be  aware  there  might  be  something  you  will  wish  to  see ...
This is almost a well kept secret in town ...
You will not be disappointed, guaranteed.

reviews.title: A brief glimpse into Toronto's history.
text: This authentic council chamber is filled with photographs from the 1920's and 30's depicting the public and sporting life of the era.
See pictures of the early Exhibition, sporting grounds, rowers, marathon swimmers, baseball teams, and more.
Also, see ( but don't sit in ) the Mayor's chair from the era - it's impressive.
It will only take an hour to glimpse this vignette into Toronto's history.

reviews.title: Market Gallery - a quick break for history
text: Above the St. Lawrence Market (and with a view of all the stalls and customers below) the Market Gallery is a quick getaway to a quiet, spacious gallery housed in the old City Council Chamber. Enjoy the changing exhibitions of everyday Toronto history from the city archives.

reviews.title: Large Market.
text: Loved this place.  Find any kind of cheese you like and delicious breads, meats and any kind of delicatessen you can imagine from all over the world.

reviews.title: Hidden secret of Toronto
text: This is a gallery to visit by visitors and residents alike. it usually has exhibits of archival materials about Toronto, Ontario and Canada.

At this time and until September 26, there is an exhibit named Home Field Advantage: Toronto's Summer Sporting Sites. it is dedicated to the PAN Am/PARAPAN Am games, which are taking place in GTA Jul/Aug 2015.
I would strongly recommend a visit to the Market Gallery

reviews.title: Gallery shares Toronto History
text: The Market Gallery, on the 2nd floor of the south St. Lawrence Market, is a gem. It's wonderful to have that relaxing, beautiful space with changing exhibits where one can go to and escape. It's a great spot to stop and enjoy some history and culture in the heart of Toronto....and it's FREE!
